details.bio:
~ Exile - A Dark Universe ~

Elrick stepped up to the portal and brought his Time Lord mask down over his face. A stream of coordinates and dates ran across the screen in front of his eyes. He winked to lock them in and the words Verrouillage: L'Univers Seripharadis ran bold across his vision. There was a whirring and a pop as the portal before him shifted to show open space with stars twinkling.

There was something off about that twinkling. Something twisted. He squinted to study the universe before him. It was darker than before, several stars had shifted in their position, and an overwhelming thrumming pulsed against his mask.

Before he could step through to investigate, the voice of Lavoisier, Master of Time, called out, “Where you off to?”

Elrick waved a dismissive hand, replying, “After documenting Cthulhu ripping apart another universe, I need a vacation.”

“That’s not our way.”

“I need a minute to get my head straight.”

“Don’t take long,” Lavoisier urged. “Cthulhu is on the move. I’ll need you to document the destruction left in his wake. Hopefully, by the time you get back, I’ll have a lock on the date and universe he's resurfaced in.”

Elrick’s head dropped and shook. “I can’t watch another universe fall to him. Find someone else.”

“This isn’t a request.”

“It never is,” Elrick whispered into the mask.

Lavoisier could be heard quickly approaching. “I’m sorry, what was that?”

Elrick lifted his head when a warning flashed before his eyes stating the portal would soon close. He turned to look at Lavoisier, waved with two fingers, and dropped backward into the open space of Seripharadis, the origin universe of the Time Lords.

Once through, Elrick’s eyes adjusted to see what had broken. Seriph, the star that was once an ancient dragon of time, had twisted in on itself. The beloved star that had given birth to all Time Lords was now turned inside out, pulling other stars into its vacuous embrace. He could feel its touch gripping at his suit and tugging. He was far enough away that there wasn't any real danger to him yet, but soon that may no longer be the case.

Before he could turn back, something shifted within the blackhole. No… That’s not quite right. Whatever it was, floated between the blackhole and Elrick.

With a terrible shock, he realized what it was and glared at the monstrous god, so nearly, perfectly camouflaged against the spiraling black that had replaced Seriph.

“Cthulhu.” The name fell out of him in the form of a vile curse.

Upon speaking it, though the elder god appeared too far off to hear, a tentacle on the monster’s head twitched and the titan glanced ever so slowly back at Elrick. Bright, red eyes pierced through Elrick’s mask and into his soul.

The words ‘welcome, Time Lord’ erupted in Erlick’s mind, followed by a pulsating, thrumming that made him nearly rip the mask away to take pressure off his head.

Elrick winked and the screen before his eyes lit up with a command prompt that read: Input Destination. He thought of the Time Lord Library as he’d left it. The coordinates ran across the screen. He winked and the words Verrouillage: Bibliothèque de Temps ran bold across the screen.

When the screen dimmed, floating directly outside his mask was the colossal visage of Cthulhu. A wicked smile spread across the elder gods face as evil eyes watched a portal flash and open.

“NO!” Elrick screamed.

Cthulhu let out a deep, pulsating chortle and replied both in Elrick’s mind and out loud into the Seripharadis universe with a low, prolonged, vibrating, “Yyyeeesss.”

Elrick winked and the screen reappeared. An attempt to send the mental command FORCE CANCEL was battered down and mauled to shreds by a sudden, intense thrumming. Blood ran from Elrick’s nose as the display flickered and went dark. Something pinched him around the middle and, within the sea of black, pain sprouted along his spine, blossomed at the back of his neck, and branched across his ribs. Coughing followed by a wheezing escaped as air was crushed from his lungs. Red splattered across the lens of his mask driving home the imminent realization that he was out of time and would soon cease to exist. He slammed his palms against whatever was piercing his suit and closed his eyes to muster as much focus as possible to absorb time from Cthulhu.

The word ‘Pathetic’ was spat into the back of Elrick’s mind followed by a rushing motion as his body was hurled through space toward the blackhole. The contents of his stomach joined the blood on his lens and a hissing could be heard. A horrific truth clawed through his gut to crawl coldly up to strangle all other thought: The suit that protected him within the dead of open space was rapidly emptying itself of the gasses and fluids that sustained him.

Something bright blurred beyond the smears staining the lens of his mask. A few seconds passed and there was a lightning blast of blue. And, then, the blurry mirage of a radiant blue dragon stretching wide its wings filled the lens from left to right. He closed his eyes, believing it would soon blind him, only to see the image burnt into the back of his eyelids.

Something wrapped around his fist, and he felt his trajectory swiftly twist and shift back the way he had come. Within little more than an instant, he felt the familiar static of passing through a portal and then his chest made rough contact with a solid floor.

Certain Cthulhu was toying with him, he tried to grab whatever was wrapped around his fist. It gracefully crossed from one hand to wrap around the opposite. Something else grabbed him around the shoulders and he felt himself being dragged across the floor. The sound of an emergency door seal slamming down and locking tight could be heard behind him and then light erupted when his mask was pulled off.

Lavoisier stood over him, attempting to clean the mask out with his bare hand. “I thought you were dead.”

Elrick put a hand to his stomach where he’d been pierced. “I think I might be.” His hand came away smattered in blood. Then the nightmare replayed in his head. “Cthulhu!”

“Yes, we must beat him to the Library.” Lavoisier stopped and narrowed his eyes at Elrick’s hand. “What is that?”

Elrick’s eyes went wide and he glanced sideways at a small, black dragon. Blue energy pulsed through its wings, chest, mouth, and eyes as the creature’s head tilted from side to side to study them in return.

“I think this little guy saved my life,” Elrick said.

“Looks to be a girl,” Lavoisier corrected. “But we can talk about all that later. We have work to do.”

Elrick jolted when he heard an explosion. “Cthulhu is attacking us.”

“Yes. Please do try to keep up.”

“Our people!”

“They can only follow after the Library.” Lavoisier handed the mask back to Elrick as he helped him to his feet. “Therefore, moving the Library to a new universe is our priority.”

The dragon watched the window as something orange and blazing whizzed by outside. Elrick followed the creature’s gaze to see Cthulhu launching from one star ship to another, tearing gaping holes through starship hulls. Time Lords were floating through open space without suits on.

“They never had a chance. This is my fault and they’re all going to die if we don’t do something.”

“Their lives may be lost,” Lavoisier admitted, “But they’ll truly be lost forever if we don’t save the Library. Through the Library, their names will live on for all eternity.”

“Wake up, Lavoisier. Our people are out there choking to death on the vacuum of space. We must return fire.”

“We don’t have any military vessels, Elrick.” 

“We did this to ourselves.”

“It’s who we are.” Lavoisier said as he opened a portal. “Never interfere. Only document.”

“Even to save ourselves?” Elrick couldn’t believe what he was hearing. “How could we be so arrogant to think he’d never come for us.” He watched Lavoisier step through the portal into the Library and sit at the Master of Time’s captain seat. “Your foolish doctrine is blinding you to what that Library truly is. It’s a weapon that sucks life from stars!” He limped toward the portal. “Turn the siphon on Cthulhu and we could end this here and now.”

“We can’t use it for that,” Lavoisier said. “That’s not who we are.”

“Then we must evolve our thinking!”

“Your name will forever be documented in the Library as an honored Time Lord.” Lavoisier said, nodding a curt goodbye.

“Don’t you dare,” Elrick threw out a hand and sent a tendril of time energy to catch the portal.

With a wave, the Master of Time dispelled it.

“Coward!” Elrick roared as he used what strength he had left to lunge for the portal.

Lavoisier held out a palm and a tendril of bright light shot through the portal and into Elrick.

Time slowed to a near stop, yet the dragon tilted her head from side to side as quickly as ever to study the Master of Time through the portal.

Lavoisier looked back curiously and then waved a hand.

The portal snapped shut.

Elrick’s time sped back up to normal and his broken body met the floor with a crash.

A screech of protest came from the dragon as Elrick pulled himself up onto a knee. He sighed, glancing at the creature. “I’m afraid you saved my life to die at my side.”

The dragon appeared to shrug in a most adorably nonchalant way while staring curiously at the portal that opened ahead of the massive Time Lord Library starship. She chirped and flapped her wings, yet remained fastened to Elrick’s hand.

“If you can get there, little one, you should go.”

She chirped again and then looked in the opposite direction.

Elrick turned to see Cthulhu rushing toward the portal.

“I should be upset, but we deserve this.”

The dragon made a face that bore the likeness of an angry scolding.

“What do you expect this broken body to do against something so powerful?”

She flapped her wings and pointed her face at the monstrosity as he passed by.

“Don’t,” Elrick snapped. “He’ll kill you with a look.”

The next thing he felt was his arm being pulled out of socket as the little dragon exploded forward in the form of a brilliant, blue beam of time energy. Cthulhu didn’t even have a chance to give the look Elrick had mentioned before she pierced through his chest.

Every wrinkle in the elder god’s rubbery figure lit up with the same blue energy, his massive, grotesque body stopping abruptly mid-flight.

The starships that remained somewhat intact moved quickly to line up and one by one they began zipping forward and through to the new universe.

The blue that coursed through Cthulhu began to pale and before the final ship could pass through the portal, the monster managed to break free and took chase. The ship was partially through when the portal slammed shut with a cosmic boom, tearing the starship in half.

Cthulhu’s roar rumbled and the ship Elrick remained in rocked. The elder god took hold of the ship broken by the portal, as a child might a toy boat at bath time, and flung it, with all its dying passengers, deeper into space. He twirled and with a blinding speed approached Elrick.

Slamming his mask back over his head, Elrick tried to enter panicked, mental commands into a flickering screen. “Come on, come on, come on.”

Erupting in his head were the words, ‘Let’s have a chat, shall we?’

Elrick stopped struggling with the mask and took it off to see a huge, glowing, red eyeball staring through the window at him.

“If you’re going to kill me,” said Elrick, “get to it.”

The massive red eye shifted to a dark green with gold speckles. ‘They abandoned you.’

“Mice tend to scatter when the cat pounces.”

That deep, rumbling, chortle erupted, shaking the ship. “You’ve got me there.” This time the words were not in his mind and the ship shuddered under the weight of it. The eye shifted to Elrick’s hand. “Your friend stopped me cold. Nothing has ever done that before. I'm impressed.”

Elrick felt, more than saw, the dragon reappearing around his hand.

“No reason we can’t be friends,” Cthulhu mused, “you and I.”

Elrick scoffed at the thought. “You can’t be serious?”

“I need soldiers like yourself.”

The eye appeared to look inside of Elrick. He could feel the layers of his mind and soul being flipped through like pages of a diary.

After perusing the first few chapters the monster grew bored with the story and closed the book. “You’re angry with your people for letting this happen. For not fighting me sooner.”

“Infuriated.”

“Then set your anger with me aside and let us hunt them together.” He pulled away from the window far enough to show Elrick his wicked smile. “We'll kill that old coward and put you in his throne as the new Master of Time. Then, if you're still mad at me, you can have a go at–how did your internal story remember it–turning the siphon on me to end me here and now.”

Elrick tried to match the smile. “Now, that sounds like a story I'd read.”

“All in good time, baby mouse.” Cthulhu looked Elrick over and waved a talon in a circle. The wounds closed and Elrick was finally able to take a breath.

The dragon appeared appalled by the energy and crawled into Elrick’s Time Lord Void Pocket to hide.

Cthulhu grabbed the ship Elrick was in and opened a portal of his own, this one dark and menacing. “All in good time.”

It took everything Elrick could muster to steady himself as they rushed through the portal.

Once on the other side, massive Eldritch monsters could be seen floating in space, awaiting Cthulhu’s return. 

Despite being surrounded by horrors, Elrick couldn't help but smirk as he thought to himself: I’m lucky he was too lazy to keep flipping through my pages. Worst mistake he’ll ever make.

~ Derelict ~

To be revealed…

damageVulnerabilities: Highly Vulnerable to Necrotic (See Unholy Sensitivity)

system.description:
• A creature can use its action to eat one berry.
    • Eating a berry restores 1 hit point, and the berry provides enough nourishment to sustain a creature for one day.
    • The berries lose their potency if they have not been consumed within 24 hours of the casting of this spell.

• If you are able to make multiple attacks with the Attack action, this maneuver replaces one of them.
  • You may use your Disarm maneuver to attempt to knock an item or weapon from a creature's hand.
    • The target must be within your reach and be holding an item (either carried or wielded).
      • The target makes a Strength or Dexterity saving throw against your maneuver DC.
        • The target has advantage if it is larger than you or holding the item with two or more hands
        • Alternatively, a target smaller than you has disadvantage.
          • On a failure, you deal basic melee damage and the target drops the item in its space.

• Allows a character to evade opportunity attacks for the rest of their turn.
    • It’s a defensive tactic used when you want to safely move away from an enemy without risking a free swing.

• While you cannot grapple a creature two or more size categories larger than you, you can grab onto it.
    • By jumping onto its back or climbing up a limb, you can make a Strength or Dexterity saving throw against the creature's maneuver DC to cling to or balance upon its body.
      • On a success, you move into the creature's space and can move upon its body as if it is difficult terrain.
  • While grabbing onto a larger creature, you gain advantage on attack rolls against it.
    • The larger creature may be able to attack you as normal, depending on its limbs or attacks.
      • It can also use an action or replace one of its attacks on its turn to try to dislodge you, such as shaking you loose or bashing you against a wall, forcing you to make a Strength or Dexterity saving throw against its maneuver DC or fall prone into the nearest space adjacent to the creature, taking its basic melee damage in the process.
  • If the creature chooses to roll over in order to dislodge you, it becomes prone, but you have disadvantage on the saving throw to hang on.

• If you are able to make multiple attacks with the Attack action, this maneuver replaces one of them.
  • You can use the Grapple maneuver to grab or wrestle a creature
    • You must have at least one free hand to attempt a grapple, your target must be within your reach, and the target must be no more than one size category larger than you.
      • The target makes a Strength or Dexterity saving throw against your maneuver DC.
        • On a failure, you deal basic melee damage and the target becomes grappled.
          • In addition to things that end the condition, you can release the target at any time (no action required).
  • Escaping a Grapple
    • While grappled, a creature can use its action to attempt to escape. It must succeed on a Strength or Dexterity saving throw against your maneuver DC.
  • Moving a Grappled Creature
    • When you move, you can drag or carry the grappled creature with you.
      • When you do so, your Speed is halved, unless the creature's weight is within your carrying capacity and you are not encumbered by bulky items.
  • Freeing a Grappled Creature
    • You can use the Grapple maneuver to try to free another grappled or restrained creature.
      • The creature grappling or restraining the target makes a Strength saving throw against your maneuver DC.
        • If it fails the saving throw, the grappled or restrained creature is freed.
        • Additionally, you may move the freed creature 5 feet in any direction.

• If you are able to make multiple attacks with the Attack action, this maneuver replaces one of them.
  • You can use the Knockdown maneuver to trip or push a creature down.
    • The target must be within your reach and be no more than one size category larger than you.
    • The target makes a Strength saving throw against your maneuver DC.
      • On a failure, you deal basic melee damage and knock the target prone.

• You can use an action or bonus action to make an Overrun maneuver to move through a hostile creature's space by forcing your way past.
    • Make a Strength saving throw against the target's maneuver DC.
      • On a success, you deal basic melee damage and can move through the hostile creature's space once this turn.
      • The creature can choose to let you pass instead of rolling.
      • You have advantage if you are larger than the target, or disadvantage if you are smaller.
      • If you are two or more sizes smaller than the target, you can move through the hostile creature's space without making a save.
      • You still provoke opportunity attacks if you move beyond a creature's reach.

• If you are able to make multiple attacks with the Attack action, this maneuver replaces one of them.
  • You can use the Shove maneuver to push a creature away.
    • The target must be within your reach and be no more than one size category larger than you.
      • The target makes a Strength saving throw against your maneuver DC.
        • On a failure, you deal basic melee damage and push the target a number of feet away from you equal to 5 + 5 for every 5 points it failed its saving throw by.
          • You can move the creature in any direction away from you (to the side, forward, or diagonally away).
    • A creature that is shoved off of a precipice is propelled off of whatever it is standing on -- it does not receive any saving throw or ability check to grab onto something to avoid falling down below.

• Taking the Dash action gives you additional movement, equal to your speed, for the current turn.
    • For a creature with a walking speed of 30ft, this means their movement for that turn would increase to 60ft.
      • This bonus includes any modifiers to your speed
      • This also applies to negative modifiers
      • Note: A situation that often causes confusion is when you Dash after standing up from being prone, which costs half of your movement.
        • Creatures with 30ft speed who are standing up from being knocked prone only has 15ft of movement remaining, but Dash doubles the original 30ft, and therefore they can move 45ft after getting up from being knocked prone.

• When you take the Dodge action, you focus entirely on avoiding attacks.
    • Until the start of your next turn, any attack roll made against you has disadvantage if you can see the attacker.
    • Additionally, you make Dexterity saving throws with advantage.
    • Note: You lose these benefits if you are incapacitated or if your speed drops to 0.

• Instead of using a weapon to make a melee weapon attack, you can use an unarmed strike: a punch, kick, head-butt, or similar forceful blow (none of which count as weapons).
    • On a hit, an Unarmed Strike deals bludgeoning damage equal to 1 + your Strength modifier.
      • You are proficient with your unarmed strikes.
      • This damage cannot be halved by a saving throw.
• At 2nd level, when Myra hits you with a Summoned Energizing Arrow, it grants Elrick LeCost 1 to his Time Pool.

system.description:
• Longswords that attach directly to the hip of the Time Lord who owns them and is considered Versatile.

    • These blades are perfectly balanced and weighted so their master can dual wield them.

    • These blades can switch between the regular Metallic Attack or Time Thirst Attack:

      • Metalic Attack

        • Does the usual long blade damage of your attack action (1d8 + Strength Slashing Damage) and bonus action while ***Dual-Wielding (1d8 Slashing Damage)

          • Alternatively, one blade can be used ***Two-Handed (1d10 + Strength)

      • Time Thirst Attack

        • They can trigger your Time Thirst ability against the creature successfully struck by them (once upon the main action, and then again on the bonus action while dual wielding).

    • ***You can only Dual-Wield or Two-Handed wield these weapons if Seriphina is no longer curled around one of your fists.

    • When these blades are knocked from their master’s hands, or thrown, they reappear on their master’s hip or in their hand as a free action when recalled.

    • If taken up by anyone besides their master, a pulse of time energy displaces the creature who touched them 10 feet along the path they previously took and the blade is instantly returned to their master’s hip or hand

      • Unless the creature does not have the ability to share the same space as another, they go an additional 5 feet along their previous path until they end in an area not currently occupied by another creature.

• A mask that summons up information on the history of each universe Time Lord's monitor.
    • Gain Advantage to all History Checks

Includes:

  • 1x Backpack

  • 1x Book (Lore)

  • 1x Ink (1 ounce Bottle)

  • 1x Ink Pen

  • 10x Parchment, Sheet

  • 1x Sand Bag

  • 1x Knife, Small
Capacity: 30 pounds of gear or 1 cubic foot. You can also strap items, such as a bedroll or a coil of rope, to the outside of a backpack.
• When writing on this tablet, the notes rapidly fade and appear in the Time Lord Library of Histories.
Ink is typically used with an ink pen to write.
An ink pen is a wooden stick with a special tip on the end. The tip draws ink in when dipped in a vial and leaves an ink trail when drawn across a surface.
A sheet of parchment is a piece of goat hide or sheepskin that has been prepared for writing on.
A small bag of sand, typically found in a Scholar's Pack.
A blunt knife used by the scholarly to open letters and correspondence.

• Seriphina - Fluid

    • Why she chose you, you have no idea, but she’s highly protective when outside the Void Pocket, refusing to leave Elrick’s hand for longer than a moment or two.

      • Seriphina has a number of actions that are equal to your proficiency bonus.

      • Her actions have a distance equal to 10 times your proficiency bonus.
      • Elrick must use his reaction to use her actions.

      • She can be sent to the Void Pocket as a free action, but immediately finds a place to sleep once inside and does not resurface until a short or long rest.

      • She may fluidly go in and out of Elrick’s Void Pocket freely to free up his hands to Dual-Wield, Two-Handed wield, or use his bow.

      • After all her actions are expended she phases out until you take a short/long rest, freeing your hands up to Dual-Wield your swords, Two-Handed wield one sword, or use your bow.

        • She gets half her actions back during a short rest (rounded up) and all her actions back on a long rest.

      • When she first materializes after a short/long rest, you may choose a new trait from the following:

        • Timeless Dragon

          • The number of her actions are doubled.

        • Temporal Dragon

          • Her actions can be used freely and at any time, rather than just as reactions.

        • Enduring Dragon

          • Her distance is doubled.

        • Fluid Dragon

          • She can go in and out of Elrick’s Void Pocket freely to free up his hands to Dual-Wield, Two-Handed wield, or use his bow.

effects.name: Seriphina: Fluid
effects.description: • The number of her actions are equal to Elrick's proficiency bonus.

system.description:
• The Void Pocket is a Vampire Time Lord’s answer to storing their artifacts and valuables in safe, impenetrable storage.

    • As a bonus action, a Time Lord can open a split in time and space to put something into the Void Pocket.

    • Alternatively, they may use a bonus action to think of something within the Void Pocket and let it drop out within 5 feet of them.

      • Takes no additional action to catch whatever was dropped.

• Legend has it, the Vampire Time Lords descended from Seriph, an ancient dragon god who became a star upon his death.

    • The ashes that erupted from this transformation landed upon an orbiting planet and from those ashes rose the first Time Lords.

      • All Time Lords are immune to radiant damage due to this lineage.

• Living a life violating the privacy of others has developed within you the need to be invited into the residences of those you don’t consider hostile toward you or your party.

    • Without this, you refuse to enter, and wait patiently outside.

• Vampire Time Lords are vulnerable to necrotic damage, and can never benefit from immunity or resistance to it.

    • If you deal necrotic damage to a creature in any way (Through class feature, spell, item, etc) you suffer the same amount of necrotic damage you dealt.

      • This also affects you if another creature or thing uses you as a conduit of necrotic energy.

• Many Vampire Time Lords go through an extensive, magical process that permanently erases their reflection from every reflective surface.

    • Since your exile, you painfully regret the decision to partake in that process.

      • Whenever you look into any surface that would normally reveal your reflection (Such as still water or a mirror) you suffer psychic damage equal to 1d4 + your proficiency bonus.

        • The damage from this gets worse as you level up because your desire to see your reflection gets worse the longer you go knowing you won’t ever get to see it.
• Vampire Time Lords are unable to be charmed, frightened, or controlled in any way, including magical manipulations.

cJwSTd8eStqq3588.name: Tongues Charisma Modifier
cJwSTd8eStqq3588.description: You may add 1d10 toward convincing a creature of something outside of combat.

system.description:
• You can understand all spoken and unspoken languages, and creatures who can understand at least 1 language understand what you are saying and appreciate the perfect way you speak their language as if you were always one of their own.

    • For this reason, you may add 1d10 toward convincing a creature of something outside of combat.

      • You may only use this once per creature per month unless you use 2 from your Time Pool to use it again on that same creature before a month has passed.

      • Examples: Convincing a creature to calm down, convincing a creature it's in their best interest to choose peace over violence, Convincing a creature you’re telling the truth (add to the Deception Check if you’re lying).

• A Vampire Time Lord specializes in their ability to enter areas in order to take better notes.

    • As long as a hole is an inch or larger, they can become a Mist and pass through unseen.

    • Alternatively, they may choose to become a Mist and vanish upon movement.

        • Roll Stealth + Proficiency on a DC 15.

          • If successful they become invisible and avoid attacks of opportunity from all creatures who cannot see the invisible.

    • This ability can be used a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, refreshing all uses at dawn.

• A Vampire Time Lord may use dash as a bonus action on their turn.

    • When you dash as a bonus action this way, you may not use your action to dash.

  • Additionally, when rolling for initiative, you roll an additional 1d6. (auto applied)

• Vampire Time Lords have the ability to cling to any surface that is not magical and are agile climbers, matching your climbing speed to your walking speed (Impossible Speed buff applies).

    • You are able to move up, down, and across vertical surfaces and upside down along ceilings.

      • When you stop, your body adheres to the surface and frees up your hands for note taking (or other uses now that you’re exiled).

• At 1st level, hence at birth, a Vampire Time Lord is ruled by the need to absorb time from something else and your soul demands to be sated by absorbing time.

    • You gain a Time Pool equal to the amount shown in the Fabled Vampire Time Lord Class Table.

      • To sate your thirst, you must absorb the Time Pool of other creatures or things.

        • As an action you may absorb the time from a creature within 5-feet of you that remains alive by touching them.

          • They take an unavoidable 1d6 damage and you add 1 to your Time Pool.

            • If a creature’s max HP is reduced to 0 from this feature, they die and you gain 2 to your Time Pool instead of 1.

        • Alternatively, you can absorb time from objects, consuming useful weapons or objects in the process to recover 1 to your Time Pool.

      • If not within your Time Lord Haven when taking a long rest, your Time Pool depletes by an amount equal to your proficiency bonus.

        • If there is not enough time in the pool to be depleted, then it depletes the remaining amount and you gain a level of exhaustion until you sate your remaining thirst.

          • This exhaustion can not be removed by any means except absorbing time from something.

            • The exhaustion consumes one from the Time Pool you’re attempting to recover and then you are no longer exhausted.

  • History: Time Lords refuse to alter living universes and dedicate their lives to documenting the histories of all known living universes.

    • The best way they’ve found to accomplish this, while allowing themselves to feed on the time of others, is to find a universe that has lost all its life, and park the Time Lord Library of Histories a safe distance from a new star.

      • Since stars live between 50 million to 20 billion years, the Time Lord’s have a substantial amount of time to park their star fleets nearby to absorb time from the star without harming a living universe.

        • If life begins to miraculously resurface within the dead universe of the star being drained, the Time Lord’s move to another dead universe and start the process over again.

effects.name: Seriphina: Fluid
effects.description: • The number of her actions are equal to Elrick's proficiency bonus.
